newsitem.title: USA: Fort Howard, Flagstar to recoup taxes under law.
newsitem.headline: Fort Howard, Flagstar to recoup taxes under law.

text.p: Two U.S. companies, Fort Howard Corp and Flagstar Cos Inc, will recoup millions of dollars in taxes that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) claims they owe, thanks to a recent change in federal tax legislation.
Fort Howard, a Green Bay, Wis.-based maker of consumer tissue products, said Friday it expects to reverse a $43 million reserve it took for potential tax payments, plus accrued interest.
The one-time gain for reversal of the reserve likely will be taken in 1997, Cliff Bowers, a Fort Howard spokesman, said.
Bowers said Fort Howard established its reserve a few years ago as part of an ongoing dispute with the IRS concerning the deductibility of debt financing costs stemming from a 1988 leveraged buyout.
Flagstar, a Spartansburg, S.C.-based restaurant company, said it expects to recoup the majority of the $12.7 million in tax the IRS said it owes.
The company said the majority of the $12.7 million in potential tax liabilities reflects deductions for borrowings and other costs that the IRS disallowed.

In the case of Fort Howard, Bowers said the company stands to negate the disputed tax payments under a provision attached to the minimum wage law signed by President Bill Clinton on August 20. That new provision would allow certain debt associated with Fort Howard's leveraged buyout to be deducted.
It was not immediately known how many other companies could potentially benefit from the new tax provision.
